Damon three amalaki dictum home your
desk our Gator Narendra Modi is a leader
of India's Hindu nationalist party the
party agenda Party or BJP is predicted
to be a strong favourite in national
elections New York Times correspondents
provide a profile of the man who may be
India's next prime minister beginning
with his controversial past in 2002
there was news that a train of Hindu
activists had stopped in the town of
Godhra in Gujarat in the midst of a
Muslim slum one of the cars was set on
fire and 59 Hindus died gastly deaths it
is thought that the Muslims set fire to
one of the cars of the train what
followed in the next days was a horrific
bloodletting of Hindu mobs attacking
Muslims I arrived not long afterwards I
remember going to the site of one of the
most notorious of the massacres that
occurred there at the gleborg Society
and I could smell the the roasted flesh
of the people who had burned to death in
that house witnesses were telling me
that they had begged the police to
intervene and stop the mobs and that
they stood by and that leaders of groups
affiliated with the Bharatiya Janata
Party were inciting the violence a
couple of months after the violence I
went back to Gujarat because I wanted to
find out
more about what it actually happened I
interviewed the Chief Minister of
Gujarat Narendra Modi I asked him if he
had any regrets about what had happened
in his state in that period women were
openly raped hundreds and hundreds of
people were killed he told me his his
greatest regret was that he didn't
manage the media very well I left the
interview feeling chilled by my
interview with the Chief Minister he had
not shown any regret or expressed any
any empathy for those who had been
slaughtered in his State on his watch I
don't believe he's ever granted another
interview to two New York Times reporter
ever since mr. Modi is not charged for
any crime during the Raj tilde but there
are widespread allegation that the
intention was to polarize the politics
so that the Hindu voters can vote for
them since then mr. Modi is winning the
elections in Gujarat again and again he
claims that he has been lots of
developmental work in Gujarat to some
extent those claims are right
Gujarat has grown about 10 percent a
year for the last ten years and that
scene is when a mr. Modi's biggest
accomplishments as chief minister mr.
Modi's had a great effort to reach out
to businesses of all sizes but in
particular two large businesses he's
made great efforts to recruit Indian
corporations and multinational
corporations to come to Gujarat to set
up production facilities there just at a
portion he's done so in large part by
cutting the red tape that is endemic in
an Indian government there is a big
question about whether everybody in
Gujarat has benefited from from the
growth of the state supporters of mr.
Modi say that the growth has been
broad-based and it's helped every
Gujarati but critics say that the growth
has not been even in particular they
worry that Muslims have been left behind
in this growth there's also a
potentially disruptive element in the
relation
the United States which took a fairly
hard line in rebuking him his visa
privileges were revoked a few years
after the riots this is quite an unusual
step for the US government to take and
although Modi talks very little about
this in his campaign it has to be an
issue for him if he becomes Prime
Minister he will be able to come and go
to the United States as a world leader
what this issue has to be something that
made an impact on him now he has been
extremely careful to avoid any
inflammatory language during his
campaign and and really restyled himself
as a technic rat
and been careful to avoid anything that
could be seen as divisive but that
question remains open you can find
people on both sides of this divide and
some people say he's just a very
dangerous candidate for that reason
